newsitem.title: UK: NWE naphtha, in contango, tumbles to six-month low.
newsitem.headline: NWE naphtha, in contango, tumbles to six-month low.

text.p: NWE naphtha prices tumbled to their weakest levels since last August and swaps inverted into contango on a host of bearish fundamentals that punctuated a three-week downtrend, traders said.

Weaker crude oil futures, ample supply in Northwest Europe, traders pressuring the swaps to capitalise on cargoes they hold in the Mediterranean, and signs that end-users were looking at alternative feedstocks -- all were cited as reasons for the sharp naphtha drop.
One end-user said that because of the contango, traders were trying to place vessels for the first half of March instead of the second half, further hurting prices.
He said traders were still trying to ship Med cargoes to the Far East, but the arbitrage had already shut.
March swaps last traded $11.50 lower at $192/$193 a tonne and April dropped $7.50 to $193/$194. The swaps were in backwardation of $3-$4 just a few days ago.
NWE cargoes were notionally valued at $191/$195 cif.
The end-user said a 5,000-10,000 tonne Russian cargo was offered at $195 cif, with the closest bid under $190.

"I would say it's an oversupplied market," the end-user said. He said he was starting to look at LPG as an alternative feedstock for March, which could replace a cargo of naphtha, but that he had not bought any yet.
Two to three cargoes of 20,000-30,000 tonnes were trying to be placed for the first half of the month, but the end-user said his needs were already covered.
